review_title: Great Company, little room for growth
pros: benefits are great and the company prides itself on its diversity. They have a strong "bring your whole self to work" policy.
cons: No room to move up. If you're on a team and want something new, you have to do a lateral transfer and then you're at the bottom of the list of employees, which means you get the garbage jobs no one else wants. You have to try to stand out in a group of people that already has great rapport with their manager. They do offer some additional learning opportunities to earn badges. However, they have no path for using the newly learned information. They don't offer much in the way of pay raises either. Typically, they give a 1.99999% raise a year. If you think getting a promotion will get you paid more, I've been told that at **most** you **might** get a 10% raise, but all I've heard from most people is that they consider the 2% raise your raise to go with your promotion.

job_title: Relationship Account Officer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Macro managed. Your in control of your own success. Management supported and respected each individuals chosen career path equally. For example, An individual that valued a work life balance was not treated or managed any different than the individual that valued working 70 hours a week to fast track a career path.
cons: Training was very scattered, unorganized and a majority of it was peer driven. I was forcefully placed on disability leave while incapacitated due to prolonged complications from COVID -19. It was very obvious that my termination was expedited due an unauthorized leave of absence that i wasn't aware was placed on. By the time i had recovered enough to try to understand the reality of the devi stating consequences it caused for my family, I called and was told no information could be given because i was no longer an employee and the three sentence termination letter stating that I took an unauthorized leave of absence that I never requested or initiated, and that i will also be considered not re-hire able should answer any questions I have. As soon as I can get back on my feet and somehow get a job in the industry i have been in for over 18 years, and fix my rent history and pay down my utility bills, I will be perusing legal counsel to have my termination investigated as a wrongful termination.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Irvine, CA
pros: End of year bonuses (About $600-$700 after taxes)
cons:
-They take advantage of you.. Hired as 20hr teller, Forced to work full time with only part time benefits. Promised to make me a full time on paper but never delivered. As it turns out they do this to all CSRs. In our market there's only ONE employee that was able to get that status. 
-Toxic environment
-No work/life balance. This job sucks the life out of you. 
-Teller system outdated compared to Chase/Wells 
-Always understaffed based on traffic but at full capacity according to the district leader.
-Take customers in even when the branch is "closed" sometimes customers would be at the branch up to 1 hr after closing.
-Shady bankers (to meet sales goals)
-During Covid we supposedly had no goals but still enforced us to meet goals and put us on the spot if we didn't by sending email to the market for everyone to see your referral rate.. On a visit, market leader basically did a huddle during working hours' trying to FORCE us to get non clients coming in for EDD to make an account. These people are coming in because of UNEMPLOYMENT and the basic checking account has to have a daily minimum balance of $1,200...
-Managers don't respect your private lives. Don't trust them, they will tell others even if you ask not to.
-Managers break a lot of policy.
-Passive Aggressive corporate life.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros: Get to work with smart driven people with the ability to shape your own career

job_title: Financial Services Representative in Lincoln, RI
pros: Good training and interaction with other employees. Exactly 15 minute breaks and 30 minute lunch feels short but gets you out on time at the end of the day. There is no room to play around, you go in, do what you are supposed to do, and leave. Which is a good thing. All your communications are heavily monitored and time tracked. Some volunteer opportunities.
cons: You can feel like a robot on the job, depending on your manager your life can be really miserable. I met some good people there and overall you're getting solid pay at a stable company with the opportunity for advancement. But being on a headset with angry people and trying to help them on a slow, outdated system really wears on you over time. If you can learn to not get stressed out by others, learn the system and learn how to talk to people, you will do decently here. But this is the worst job I've ever had. Time moves very slowly and you feel chained to your desk in a cubicle. If you don't have other things going on in your life you will be really depressed working here.

review_title: Great Compensation, but Quality Leadership is Completely MIA
pros: Being that I am part time and receive better benefits than a lot of full time positions out there, it is definitely very generous compensation. The small team I get to work with are sincerely wonderful and passionate people who work extremely hard every single day despite the lack of support from up top.
cons:
COVID has had a crippling impact on the company's culture, or at least in my center it has. They pander to the public in the media about how socially conscious they are now, but their lack of involvement in poor disenfranchised communities like mine make it clear that this is all a thinly veiled PR stunt with no substance to speak of. Upper management continues to move the goalposts with regards to their expectations for financial center employees, and they consistently fail to follow through on their word.

They routinely neglect the emotional well-being of their associates. Turnover and staff shortages are rampant with no end in sight. There is always a long hold to submit HR complaints because they are also understaffed and inundated with frustrated employees. 

Upper management seems to be willingly exploiting the dysfunction. They are completely unable and or unwilling to grasp the severity of the problems financial center staff face on a daily basis. Yet they attempt to micromanage every asinine detail of their associates' workday despite the fact they are essentially never physicslly present, opting instead to cower at home remotely while their most vulnerable staff are left to scramble together answers for leadership that refuses to accept critcism of any kind.

They want to wring their hands and deflect accountability because of the pandemic, but only in ways that suit them at the top. For regular employees who aren't given remote work options, too bad. This is why people have always felt since the beginning that "essential" is actually just code for "disposable."

job_title: Relationship Banker in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Good benefits. Seems like higher pay than other banks but relationship bankers are the lowest paid employees at the banks.
cons: I was hired for the relationship banker position and they leave out a huge part of the role in the job description and interview process. You’re a teller most of the time (possibly all of the time). This is because they are no longer hiring tellers. Relationship bankers are the lowest paid position at the banks. You get paid BofA’s minimum wage. There is nothing wrong with being a teller but that is simply not the experience and customer interaction that I was looking for. As a relationship banker working as a teller they expect you to ask probing questions and set up appointments. When you’re at the teller line and there is a line of people waiting that is unrealistic. I think that the title of the role and the description is a bait and switch tactic. They use the possibility of promotion to keep employees motivated but I saw very little signs of promotions at the two financial centers I worked at. Also, they hired me and trained me at one location but wouldn’t tell me what bank I would end up working at after training. They’re very inflexible about switching roles. You must be in your role for at least a year before they consider even transferring you to a different location. They promise that they try to place you near your house but they really don’t care. I also heard from others that they were moved to a new bank with no notice- just an email to show up at a different bank the next day. Everyone seemed unhappy.

review_title: Your experience as an employee depends on your supervisor.
job_title: Trust Senior Associate in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
I found that your experience as an employee at Bank of America depends on your supervisor. If you have a supervisor who has management experience, is fair, does not have a chip on his/her shoulder, and is not pushing any agenda, then you'll have a good experience working here. 

Another pro is that Bank of America has a pretty good benefits package.
cons:
If you have a supervisor who does not know how to manage people or who has an agenda, or who doesn't understand or abide by generally accepted workplace norms (i.e. no talking about politics in the office, no racist or sexist jokes in the office) then you'll have a bad experience working here. 

There's no use going to upper-level management or to HR to report the inappropriate behavior, either. You'll either need to suck it up and put up with the racist, sexist, homophobic, and political comments, or you'll have to find another job.

review_title: Terrible experience in the Credit Center as a Lending Officer
job_title: Commercial Lending Officer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Learning how to look up information in a policy that is 700 (seriously) pages
cons:
I was a Commercial Credit Lending Officer in the “CreditCenter” department for 3 years and had a horrendous experience.

The department has a lot of talented and hard working people but most LO’s in this department are overworked and miserable, mainly due to high turnover which strains the work capacity of all the remaining LOs. The department is a sweatshop, as everyone has to take on way too much work and struggles to keep up with their portfolios. Working efficiently in this department is very difficult as employees have to deal with convoluted procedures and primitive / glitchy computer systems. At my prior employer I won awards and was recognized as being in the top 5 producers out of 50 in my department but in this department I am continually being told I am not doing a good enough job on my unreasonable workload. 

Upper management, sitting in Chicago, should be ashamed and embarrassed by the horrible situation this department is in. Management tries to make improvements and changes, but the changes they make are just band aids. The department has been in such bad shape for so long that I don’t think management realizes how bad the situation actually is...

There are three kinds of people in the creditcenter department: New employees, those who are looking for a new job and those who have given their two week notice. Bank of America pays decently but they could have doubled my salary and I would not have stayed in the department. 
In the past three years during my employment at Bank of America I have developed a sleeping disorder, started therapy sessions, and have seen significant weight gain...I am now happy to have Bank of America in my rear view mirror.

Although they are a bank, they don’t keep their own employees being flexible in credit solutions for the employees to enjoy financial products as well. They simply don’t care for recognition at all or helping the employee grown in any way. However, focus on what you are not doing to their satisfaction. You are always criticized and pressured. You spend whole days without taking lunch (they were sued by former employees for it) they overwork and mistreat employees as they only care for customers to be seen and not for employees to have a healthy work environment. This is the reason for many employees taking FMLA and banking center being consistently understaffed.

pros: The pay sets the bar for retail banking in this role. The benefits are incredible. The company provides great resources for learning - though you will have to fight for the time to use them. Excellent employee networks that can allow you to network inside the company.
cons: Location matters, your manager matters. Good managers will support their direct reports, elevate them and help them succeed. Others may be focused only on their own success - if you find yourself with one of these managers, you end up having to look for an opportunity to transfer. Being at a strong performing location will also push your career forward, whereas being at a slow location could hinder your advancement.

review_title: Job isn't as customer focused as you would think it would/should be.
pros: Benefits are great, Pay is good and will be increasing, Diversity is top notch, Inclusion, most branches have a Community based concentration.
cons:
Relationship Banker requires you to do teller duties that aren't clearly stated in job description. 
If micromanagement isn't a good fit for you steer away from this job.
Job promotion is contingent upon which employee the manager and regional manager favor the most.
Unclear on what the requirements are to become branch manager, many that are in these positions aren't the most people friendly and don't have the best interpersonal skills needed to be a respected branch manager.
The tellers are being pressured into becoming a relationship banker to coincide with the new direction the company is headed potentially forcing many qualified employees to seek new employment or early retirement.
The work life balance leaves you tired, stressed and working 6 days out of the week which makes it hard to plan for any family events or personal time. 
Schedule requests are required for the year in advance (may be branch manager preference) which is the most unrealistic request. 
I can continue with more "Cons" but i'd rather not spend my sunday

job_title: Global Financial Crimes Investigator in Concord, CA
pros: Good company with good benefits
cons: Low pay for the region

pros:
-Knowing your hours is nice
-Good health and PTO benefits
cons:
-You don't really get trained, you will be thrown out to the floor expected to take clients and figure out how to do it as you go, which clients notice and give you a hard time for. Your manager may explain something to you one time and then get angry at you months later for missing it, and will try to cover themselves by saying they went over it with you many times.
-COLD CALLS!!! You are expected to do "proactive outreach" calls, which are just cold calls to the clients in your area with a very awkward script with no real purpose. They do not disclose this in detail at all during the hiring process. So if you don't want cold calling being a big part of your life, stay away.
-Hourly pay with no incentives, they will ask you to reach goals with no prospect of making a bonus for exceeding them
-Depending on your manager, you may be left to fend for yourself, even with angry clients. Some managers show no interest in helping you diffuse a situation, leaving you feel like you're on an island during a difficult situation.
-No flexibility. Your schedule belongs to the bank. They will deny you PTO months out and then ask you to work even when you do get approved.

review_title: repeat the same day every day
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: You do not have to be outstanding to do anything here. If you do what you're told, don't try to stand out, you can coast and get a steady paycheck. This is the job you hold if you're fine doing the same thing every day and a 3% pay rise is fine for you.
cons: 1) Ambition is not rewarded. 2) If you take a day off everything goes wrong because no one else will know how to do what you do. Your work life balance will be ruined. 3) If you go back to school expect management to assume you want to quit. The company boasts they want to change things and improve processes. What they really mean is make easier to use spreadsheets that almost automate what you do, or can automate you out. I "upskilled" myself while there and never got any offers to move up despite the company forcing us to attend meetings that explain how upskilling will help us move up in the company. They have training modules that give you worthless certifications at the end. The certifications have fancy titles. No one ever noticed or cared. The only person who did seem to notice was my immediate manager who felt if I had so much time to complete training modules then it means I don't have enough work to do. Also, you're told to do upskilling training modules in your free time but discouraged from doing it during work hours. But you're not allowed to do the modules from home. The company says one thing but does the other. And expect to be lied to by managers if you ask for a raise or want to apply to a different team. I was always able to hear my manager through the door and I know how they speak to each other. There's still some systemic racism. I didn't want to believe it at first but its there. Sexism is very obvious.

pros: Good benefits like child care reimbursement that will cover a portion of your child care expenses. 401k, medical, dental, vision, and legal. Tuition reimbursement. Shopping discounts. Associates have the same account benefits as a preferred rewards Platinum customer
cons: Poor management. Demanding schedules working 6 days a week. Constant last min changes to the schedule that are difficult to manage if you are a parent. Managers constantly give associates a difficult time about taking their annual vacation time. At the end of the current year you must schedule all your vacation time in advance for the following year. Forget trying to call out sick! Have a day off? They will insist you come in to help. Wanna take a personal day? You have to schedule it in advance with your manager when you schedule vacation time. They will ask you for specific details about what you want to do on your personal time before they consider approving it. Your personal cellphone is treated like a 24hr work phone. You will get work related messages at all hours. All the banking centers operate this way. This isn't an isolated incident to one particular center.
